  1. Show that fff is not necessarily absolutely continuous on [0,1]\br{0, 1}[0,1].

  2. We denote the variation of fff on [a,b]\br{a, b}[a,b] via

On the other hand, δ<t1<⋯<tn=1\delta < t_1 < \cdots < t_n = 1δ<t1​<⋯<tn​=1 is a partition of [δ,1]\br{\delta, 1}[δ,1], and so

    Rearranging, we see Vf([0,δ])=Vf([0,1])−Vf([δ,1])<2εV_f\p{\br{0, \delta}} = V_f\p{\br{0, 1}} - V_f\p{\br{\delta, 1}} < 2\epsilonVf​([0,δ])=Vf​([0,1])−Vf​([δ,1])<2ε, which proves the claim.

    To show that fff is absolutely continuous on [0,1]\br{0, 1}[0,1], let ε>0\epsilon > 0ε>0 and let h>0h > 0h>0 be such that Vf([0,h])≤εV_f\p{\br{0, h}} \leq \epsilonVf​([0,h])≤ε. Then shrinking hhh if necessary, we may assume without loss of generality that h∈[a1,b1]h \in \br{a_1, b_1}h∈[a1​,b1​] and so

    ∑i=1n∣f(bi)−f(ai)∣≤∣f(a1)−f(0)∣+∣f(h)−f(a1)∣+∣f(b1)−f(h)∣+∑i=2n∣f(bi)−f(ai)∣≤Vf([0,h])+∣f(b1)−f(h)∣+∑i=2n∣f(bi)−f(ai)∣≤2ε.\begin{aligned} \sum_{i=1}^n \abs{f\p{b_i} - f\p{a_i}} &\leq \abs{f\p{a_1} - f\p{0}} + \abs{f\p{h} - f\p{a_1}} + \abs{f\p{b_1} - f\p{h}} + \sum_{i=2}^n \abs{f\p{b_i} - f\p{a_i}} \\ &\leq V_f\p{\br{0, h}} + \abs{f\p{b_1} - f\p{h}} + \sum_{i=2}^n \abs{f\p{b_i} - f\p{a_i}} \\ &\leq 2\epsilon. \end{aligned}i=1∑n​∣f(bi​)−f(ai​)∣​≤∣f(a1​)−f(0)∣+∣f(h)−f(a1​)∣+∣f(b1​)−f(h)∣+i=2∑n​∣f(bi​)−f(ai​)∣≤Vf​([0,h])+∣f(b1​)−f(h)∣+i=2∑n​∣f(bi​)−f(ai​)∣≤2ε.​

    Indeed, {0,a1,h}\set{0, a_1, h}{0,a1​,h} gives a partition of [0,h]\br{0, h}[0,h], and {h,b1,a2,b2,…,an,bn}\set{h, b_1, a_2, b_2, \ldots, a_n, b_n}{h,b1​,a2​,b2​,…,an​,bn​} gives a disjoint collection of intervals in [h,1]\br{h, 1}[h,1] with total length less than δ\deltaδ, and this completes the proof.
